docs.lead_paragraph: In a study some years back, psychologists took up the issue of accurate perceptions of reality. They compared a group of clinically depressed patients with supposedly normal people and found that the nondepressed group had an exaggerated opinion of their abilities and social skills.

headline.main: Invisible Hand Now Clamping Onto Wallets; Gloomy Economic News Takes a Toll on Optimism

docs.abstract: Article discusses how much bad economic news it takes to get average person worried about money; Robert J Frank and Philip J Cook, in their Book The Winner-Take-All Society, opine that it is fundamentally human to be optimistic, but current economic downturn and dour predictions may temper such feelings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter F. Vallone, a candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, has begun broadcasting his second television advertisement on New York 1, the local cable news station. Like the first, this advertisement features former Mayor Edward I. Koch. PRODUCER -- Doak, Carrier, O'Donnell & Associates.
docs.abstract: Article assesses new television commercial for New York City Democratic mayoral hopeful Peter Vallone, which touts his proposal for prescription drug benefit for seniors and plan to make sure children have health insurance; (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Xihaitan Road leaves the center of this seaside resort and travels west toward another universe. For the first couple of miles, it runs along a dingy beach studded with looming odd-shaped boulders -- as crowded as a rush-hour subway station and as tacky as Coney Island. Chinese tourists in plastic sandals and bright bathing caps wade nearly elbow to elbow in mud-colored water and grandparents usher children toward portable carnival rides and kitschy trick photographs.

headline.main: At One Resort in China, Two Distinct Worlds

docs.abstract: Jiang Zemin is latest in long line of China's top leaders over last 40 years to take up residence each summer in West Mountain Compound in resort city of Beidaihe; Beidaihe's beauty was immortalized in well-known poem by Mao Zedong in 1950's, and supreme leader Deng Xiaoping took much publicized swims there in Bohai Sea; many seminal events in modern Chinese history are known to have taken place in Beidaihe; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A key witness in the federal investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli said he gave the legislator a series of expensive gifts in the hope of gaining his help with international business deals, a newspaper reported yesterday. In his first public remarks about some of the most serious allegations, the witness, David Chang, repeated some of what he is said to have told investigators since he began cooperating 14 months ago in their inquiry into the activities of Mr. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat.

headline.main: Witness Says He Gave Torricelli Gifts, but Received Only Promises

docs.abstract: David Chang, key witness in investigation of Sen Robert G Torricelli, says he gave expensive gifts in hope of gaining help with international business deals; expressed disappointment with help he received in return for Rolex watches, Italian suits and thousands of dollars in campaign donations; Chang asserts he is under witness protection program and that Torricalli tried to have him killed; Ted Wells, attorney for Torricelli, says Chang's comments show him to be mentally disturbed and dismisses allegations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You are right to urge senators to ensure that the final patients' rights bill ''offers stronger protections'' than the House version (editorial, Aug. 5). But we should remember that it's just a Band-Aid for a broken system: patients need these protections only because health plans' drive for profits makes them skimp on care.
docs.abstract: John Glasel letter on patients' rights legislation (Aug 5 editorial) calls for national health insurance program

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green and Peter F. Vallone turned their attention to health care issues yesterday, with speeches that outlined their plans to enroll more New Yorkers, particularly children, in health care programs. In a speech to health-care-policy experts at the Robert F. Wagner School of Public Service, Mr. Green addressed four areas -- the uninsured, children's health, medical research and the troubled public hospital system. Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker, hit on similar themes at a campaign stop at New York University Medical Center, where he proposed that the city pay the premiums currently paid by parents whose children do not qualify for Medicaid but are eligible for a low-cost insurance program. Those premiums range from $108 to $180 a year per child. He also unveiled an ambitious plan to extend prescription drug coverage to older people, seizing on an issue more commonly regarded as a federal responsibility than a local one.

headline.main: 2 Mayoral Candidates Focus on Health Care and Another Worries About the Economy

docs.abstract: Mark Green and Peter F Vallone, seeking New York City Democratic mayoral nomination, outline plans to enroll more New Yorkers, particularly children, in health care programs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the nation's biggest health insurer, said yesterday that its losses deepened in the second quarter as medical costs jumped 17 to 18 percent in its core managed care business. The company said the losses would continue into next year before it could again generate profits by raising premiums and tightening cost controls. Aetna, based in Hartford, is also shedding money-losing units that it acquired during a buying binge in the 1990's, and it may even give up its unrewarding status as the biggest, albeit hardly the best managed, health insurer.

headline.main: Aetna Posts Wider Losses, Citing High Costs in Managed Care Unit

docs.abstract: Aetna reports second-quarter operating loss of $95.9 million, compared with year-earlier operating profit of $36.4 million; predicts losses will continue into next year; puts net income, including one-time gains and charges, at $10.6 million, down from $186.6 million; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision that promises continued austerity in an election year, the government said today that it planned to cut spending by about $2.5 billion over the next 18 months to qualify for a $15 billion line of credit from the International Monetary Fund. The credit accord, announced late Friday, comes after three years of recession in Argentina and mounting concern that the government there may be forced to default on $128 billion in debt. By acting now, Brazil hopes to avoid the problems it experienced late in 1998, when a financial crisis in Asia and Russia led to a 40 percent devaluation of Brazil's currency, the real.

headline.main: Brazil Inoculating Its Economy With an Injection of Austerity

docs.abstract: Brazil plans to cut spending by about $2.5 billion over next 18 months to qualify for $15 billion International Monetary Fund line of credit; Min Pedro Milan, announcing deal in news conference with Central Bank president Arminio Fraga, holds economy is healthy and resilient; says deal is precautionary and preventive; leaves open possibility that Brazil will not draw first $4.6 billion installment in Sept; left-wing opposition scores credit deal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The PolyMedica Corporation, a leading maker of diabetes test kits, said today that the federal authorities were conducting a criminal investigation of its Liberty Medical Supply unit. Shares of PolyMedica, which is based in Woburn, fell $2.17, or 10 percent, to $18.58 before trading was halted.
docs.abstract: PolyMedica Corp, leading maker of diabetes test kits, says federal authorities conduct criminal probe of its Liberty Medical Supply unit; holds unit's operations comply with law; probe reportedly involves possible Medicare and investor fraud (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If he were mayor, Peter F. Vallone would scrap the insurance premiums that hundreds of thousands of low-income parents pay for government-subsidized health insurance for their children, his aides said yesterday. Instead, the city would pick up the cost of the premiums, which range from $108 to $180 a year per child. Campaign aides said they hoped such an incentive would compel many more parents to sign up. There are roughly 300,000 city children eligible but not yet enrolled in Child Health Plus, as the insurance program is called.
